bibl.title: Letter from H. McG. Robertson to Hugh S. Cumming, May 9, 1922

div1.p: Robertson proposes a study of fleas and bubonic plague in Boston, Philadelphia or Baltimore, Savannah, and New Orleans.

div1.head: Letter from H. McG. Robertson to Hugh S. Cumming, May 9, 1922
div1.opener:
Surgeon H. McG. Robertson.
U. S. Quarantine Station,
Marcus Hook, Pennsylvania,
May 9, 1922.
The Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
In an experience of 15 years in quarantine practice,
I have been in touch with the geographical distribution of
bubonic plague to rather an intimate degree. I have wondered
more and more, in watching the spread of this disease, that
in latitudes where cold weather prevailed for a portion of the
year plague appeared either not at all or only very occasionally
and for short periods. I have been especially struck with the
freedom of our North Atlantic seaports from this disease, knowing
that until recent years nothing of a practical nature was done
to prevent the introduction of plague through infected rats.
As late as 1911 I find that of the 1200 or more vessels arriving
at the port of Philadelphia none were fumigated, though many
came direct from ports in India and other plague infected dis-
tricts. In casting about for a reasonable explanation of this
apparent immunity of our North Atlantic Seaboard to bubonic plague,
it has seemed to me that the only plausible explanation of this
phenomenom is the absolute or relative freedom of the rodent
population from fleas during certain of the colder months of
the year. It will be readily seen that if fleas are at all
seasons present and active the spread of plague among the rats
of a community would eventually progress to a point where the
human population must become affected. If, however, in certain
seasons of more or less prolonged cold the number of fleas present
is reduced to zero or to an “Innocuous minimum”, any plague
infection which started to spread among rats at the beginning
of the “flea season” would cease automatically when fleas were no
longer present. If this “flea season” is relatively short and
rats and humans not too intimately associated, an outbreak of
human plague in any season is practically impossible. We know
that in certain of our Southern and Western cities fleas are found
at all seasons of the year.

In so far as I have learned no work has been done to
determine the seasonal prevalence of fleas in different latitudes
or in differing climates. It has been my desire for some time
to make or take some part in making such an investigation. This
was entirely apart from any idea of a survey of the rats of any
community for the existence of plague and would entail much less
expense. I understand from Assistant Surgeon General Creel that
-2-
the idea of a double survey has been put into effect at Boston
and of course it is well to know if the rats of a community are
at any time plague infected. My idea, in detail, of the work I
wish to do is as follows:

1. Make a flea survey in the following cities: Boston,
Philadelphia or Baltimore, Savannah and New Orleans. If my
supposition is correct that fleas are absent in certain of the
colder months, I believe that at some point on the coast, say
Savannah, it will be found that fleas are present on rodents in
relatively large numbers throughout the year, and that from this
point South plague could be continuously present in rats, with
the possibility of human outbreaks, while North of that, or some
near adjacent line, plague infection in rats, even if introduced
every Summer season, would as regularly die out completely during
the cold season, because of the absence of fleas, and consequently
that human plague would be hardly possible.

2. To examine at least 15 rats daily, exclusive of Sundays and
holidays, in the cities mentioned for an entire year, keeping a
record of the fleas found each day. While the identification of
all fleas found would be advisable, and I would prepare for this,
it is unnecessary in determining their absence of presence on rats.

3. Keep record of temperature and any other climatic conditions
of importance in each place where the work was done.

4. To examine all rats caught for the more obvious evidences of
plague infection, and to make smears for microscopic examination
of any organs deemed suspicious. The use of composite emulsions
in guinea pigs would in my opinion hardly justify the increased
expenditure it would make necessary.

5. The determination in the laboratory of how long a flea can
infect an animal after having fed on an infected guinea pig.
This would be of importance only as determining whether they would
retain the infection during their seclusion through several months
of cold weather.

How to
Think
into
How long do they live infected.

If this work is confined to the limits given above it
should not be unduly costly, yet it would, I think, be sufficiently
inclusive to give the desired information. As to the possible
practical good of such a work, I think it can be safely said
that the present methods of quarantine procedure might be modified
for Northern ports and that present practices in rat-proofing when
a case of human plague appears might be essentially modified. It
would of course be of great value for any community to feel
assured that the coming of cold weather would wipe out all plague
both in rats and men.

As regards my qualifications to undertake this work,
I recognize the necessity of a further and more intimate
knowledge of fleas and their habits; of rat plague and possibly
rats. I request that I be detailed for six weeks or two months
at the Hygienic Laboratory for special duty, during which time
plans for the survey can be made in detail. If it should suit
the Bureau I would like to have immediate charge of the work in
Philadelphia or Baltimore as determined, and a supervisory charge
at other places, in order that I might keep in intimate touch
with the work in its details.
